<p><strong>To mark World Mental Health Day 2022,</strong> the World Health Organization has urged making “mental health and well-being for all a global priority.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e31e9369-6229-4b18-bc04-151bfc4d2cd9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e31e9369-6229-4b18-bc04-151bfc4d2cd9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">World Mental Health Day 2022, World Health Organization, accessed October 6, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> With the growing <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/unlocking-whole-person-care-through-behavioral-health">disease burden related to brain-health conditions</a>, moving this aspiration into reality requires bold action and deep commitment from a broad range of stakeholders—with employers playing a critical role.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/jacqueline-brassey">Jacqueline Brassey</a>, <a href="/our-people/erica-coe">Erica Coe</a>, Renata Giarola, Brad Herbig, <a href="/our-people/barbara-jeffery">Barbara Jeffery</a>, and Roxy Merkand, representing views of the McKinsey Health Institute.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In our McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) publication, “<a href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem">Addressing employee burnout: Are you solving the right problem?</a>,” we highlighted what affects employee mental health and <a href="/featured-insights/well-being-in-the-workplace">well-being</a>. Now we examine who is most affected—and how leaders are in a position to improve employee mental health and well-being at scale by rethinking the workplace via a lens of a <a href="/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years">modern understanding of health</a>. Research indicates that positive outcomes—such as job satisfaction and work engagement—are correlated with feeling included and supported, and with freedom from stigma or overwhelming <a href="https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240057944">workloads</a>.</p>
<p>The insights discussed below are based on a global survey MHI conducted across 15 countries and nearly 15,000 employees. To learn more, see the sidebar, “Survey scope and methodology.”</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Employers have the opportunity to move the needle on burnout, to explore ways to help workers struggling with mental-health and well-being challenges, and to explore ways to create the healthiest environments for employees.</p></blockquote></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-edge-to-edge StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__TLkZC mck-c-module-wrapper"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Most survey respondents have experienced mental-health and well-being challenges </div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Mental health exists along a <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/using-digital-tech-to-support-employees-mental-health-and-resilience">continuum</a>, and the majority of employees are likely to experience some symptoms of poor mental health and well-being at some point during their working years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68e3da3c-2864-45a9-b0b2-71ef215b4d9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68e3da3c-2864-45a9-b0b2-71ef215b4d9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Julia Anas and Kelly Greenwood, “It’s a new era for mental health at work,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, October 4, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>According to our survey across 15 countries, around 60 percent of employees have experienced at least one mental-health challenge at some point in their lives—a figure consistent with other global research.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="00f2b2fb-df0c-4047-a374-dc125d855b14"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="00f2b2fb-df0c-4047-a374-dc125d855b14" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Includes respondents reporting to have a mental-health or substance-use diagnosis now or in the past, reporting to have sought or considered treatment for mental-health or substance-use conditions, or indicating to have experienced at least one of the following: high symptoms of anxiety, depression, distress or burnout, reporting a mental-health or substance-use-related status; see also Julia Anas and Kelly Greenwood, “It’s a new era for mental health at work,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, October 4, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> For leaders, that means that the vast majority of their employees are directly or indirectly affected by mental-health-related challenges.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="891ccf1d-1389-4aa7-9500-743af734dc36"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="891ccf1d-1389-4aa7-9500-743af734dc36" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Caryn Pearson, “The impact of mental health problems on family members,” Statistics Canada, October 7, 2015. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Companies have a role to play since the implications  of inaction in response to this crisis is tremendous. <a href="https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/363156/9789240057760-eng.pdf">Those</a> touched by mental-health and well-being challenges can’t simply be excluded or treated in isolation from the workforce; they <em>are </em>the workforce.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="exhibit 1" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>No demographic appears immune to mental-health challenges </div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Our survey reveals that employees face mental-health challenges irrespective of their country, industry, age group, role, or gender. Leaders around the world can consider how they want to prioritize helping their employees.</p>
<p>While specific groups may experience different challenges, our survey data reflect that no demographic group is immune. One example: a recent <a href="/mhi/our-insights/heat-waves-the-war-in-ukraine-and-stigma-gen-zs-perspectives-on-mental-health">McKinsey Health Institute report</a> found poor and worsening mental health among Gen Z respondents in Europe.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="exhibit 2" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Failing to address the effects of mental-health and well-being challenges is a missed opportunity for employers</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Most adults spend at least a third of their employable years at work.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c785a997-a29f-42c1-850b-b2c2c8687f57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c785a997-a29f-42c1-850b-b2c2c8687f57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“American Time Use Survey–2021 results,” Bureau of Labor Statistics, US Department of Labor, June 23, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span> The mental-health challenges create a cost for employers. Our global survey finds that employees experiencing at least one mental-health and well-being challenge (nearly three in five)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ef6664cd-8a9e-487b-9c16-7b7594e410cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ef6664cd-8a9e-487b-9c16-7b7594e410cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mental-health challenges include reporting at least one of the following now or in the past: high symptoms of anxiety, depression, distress, or burnout, or reporting a mental-health or substance-use-related status currently or in the past.</span></span></span></a></span> report worse employee experience metrics. They are three times more likely to experience toxic behaviors and four times more likely to want to leave their organization. They are also more likely to report low job satisfaction, engagement, or other signifiers of positive workplaces.</p>
<p>
</p>
<p>Yet employees may be reluctant to mention mental-health or well-being challenges, as those facing mental-health challenges may grapple with stigma. As observed in a <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace">previous McKinsey survey</a>, a substantial share of employees experiencing mental-health-related challenges indicated they would avoid treatment because they didn’t want anyone finding out. This <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/email/rethink/2021/11/17/2021-11-17d.html">terrible paradox</a> can exacerbate challenges that are often invisible to others.</p>
<p>The first step often includes <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/meet-the-psychological-needs-of-your-people-all-your-people">asking employees about the state of their mental health</a> and finding out who may need more help.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="exhibit 3" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Across all 15 countries surveyed, respondents say toxic workplace behavior has the largest effect on their intent to leave and burnout symptoms</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Many organizations have responded to the mental-health challenge facing employees by dedicating unprecedented <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/national-surveys-reveal-disconnect-between-employees-and-employers-around-mental-health-need">resources</a> to employee mental health and well-being.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4c50b9f9-fe1d-476a-9112-8f6669fb4c5d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4c50b9f9-fe1d-476a-9112-8f6669fb4c5d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Charlotte Lieberman, “What wellness programs don’t do for workers,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, August 14, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> As laudable as these efforts are, focusing on providing <a href="https://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/item.aspx?num=50306in">access to resources</a> alone may lead employers to overestimate the impact of their employee programs. They may be underestimating the critical role of other <a href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem">workplace factors</a> in supporting employee mental health and well-being.</p>
<p>Our global survey data suggest that improving workplace factors, such as eliminating toxic behaviors, boosting inclusivity, and creating sustainable work, can be several times more predictive of employee mental health and well-being than providing access to resources alone.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="exhibit 4" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/present%20company%20included%20prioritizing%20mental%20health%20and%20well%20being%20for%20all/svgz-mentalhealthallworkers-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Moving to better mental health and well-being for employees everywhere</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-3" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Survey scope and methodology</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The McKinsey Health Institute conducted</strong> a global survey in 15 countries between February and April 2022. This survey involved nearly 15,000 employees in 15 countries: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, China, Egypt, France, Germany, India, Japan, Mexico, South Africa, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States.</p>
<p>Workplace factors assessed in our survey included:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Toxic workplace behavior</em>: employees experience interpersonal behavior that leads them to feel unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers.</li>
    <li><em>Inclusivity and belonging</em>: organization systems, leaders, and peers foster a welcoming and fair environment for all employees to be themselves, find connection, and meaningfully contribute.</li>
    <li><em>Sustainable work</em>: organizations and leaders promote work that enables a healthy balance between work and personal life, including a manageable workload and work schedule.</li>
    <li><em>Supportive growth environment</em>: managers care about employee opinions, well-being, and satisfaction and provide support and enable opportunities for growth.</li>
    <li><em>Freedom from stigma and discrimination</em>: there is freedom from the level of shame, prejudice, or discrimination employees perceive toward people with mental-health or substance-use conditions.</li>
    <li><em>Organizational accountability</em>: organizations gather feedback, track KPIs, align incentives, and measure progress against employee health goals.</li>
    <li><em>Leadership commitment</em>: leaders consider employee mental health a top priority, publicly committing to a clear strategy to improve employee mental health.</li>
    <li><em>Access to resources</em>: organizations offer easy-to-use and accessible resources that fit individual employee needs related to mental health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e456c9a5-8ff1-4bd2-8119-5cf6436a6cfe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e456c9a5-8ff1-4bd2-8119-5cf6436a6cfe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Including adaptability and resilience-related learning and development resources.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>Health outcomes assessed in our survey included:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Burnout symptoms</em>: an employee’s experience of extreme tiredness, reduced ability to regulate cognitive and emotional processes, and mental distancing (Burnout Assessment Tool).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0d303a6-2e9a-43e0-94a7-d834411303fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0d303a6-2e9a-43e0-94a7-d834411303fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Steffie Desart et al., <em>User manual - Burnout assessment tool</em>, Version 2.0, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Distress</em>: an employee experiencing a negative stress response, often involving negative affect and physiological reactivity (4DSQ Distress Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eb6e8971-1c08-4194-be75-e59765865c5d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eb6e8971-1c08-4194-be75-e59765865c5d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">J. R. Anema et al., “Validation study of a distress screener,” <em>Journal of Occupational Rehabilitation</em>, September 2009, Volume 19, Issue 3.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Depression symptoms</em>: an employee having little interest or pleasure in doing things, and feeling down, depressed, or hopeless (PHQ-2 Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4f6e5522-0271-4e7a-96a4-c5529f230287"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4f6e5522-0271-4e7a-96a4-c5529f230287" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kurt Kroenke et al., “The patient health questionnaire-2: Validity of a two-item depression screener,” <em>Medical Care</em>, November 2003, Volume 41, Issue 11.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Anxiety symptoms</em>: an employee’s feelings of nervousness, anxiousness, or being on edge, and not being able to stop or control worrying (GAD-2 Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e9f5f355-0ef1-4850-8a58-298c732cb027"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e9f5f355-0ef1-4850-8a58-298c732cb027" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kurt Kroenke et al., “Anxiety disorders in primary care: Prevalence, impairment, comorbidity, and detection,” <em>Annals of Internal Medicine</em>, March 6, 2007, Volume 146, Issue 5.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>Business outcomes assessed in our survey included:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Intent to leave</em>: an employee’s desire to leave the organization in which they are currently employed in the next three to six months.</li>
    <li><em>Work engagement</em>: an employee’s positive motivational state of high energy combined with high levels of dedication and a strong focus on work.</li>
    <li><em>Organizational advocacy</em>: an employee’s willingness to recommend or endorse their organization as a place to work to friends and relatives.</li>
    <li><em>Work satisfaction</em>: an employee’s level of contentment or satisfaction with their current job.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>As we have discussed in previous articles, employers have the opportunity to move <a href="/mhi/our-insights/moving-the-needle-on-burnout">the needle on burnout</a>, to explore ways to help <a href="/mhi/our-insights/heat-waves-the-war-in-ukraine-and-stigma-gen-zs-perspectives-on-mental-health">workers</a> struggling with mental-health and well-being challenges, and to explore ways to <a href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem">create the healthiest environments for employees</a>. As employers open the aperture to look beyond the reactive management of poor mental health to the proactive mitigation of its drivers, they can reinforce what is—and is not—acceptable. For example, companies may benefit from reinforcing behaviors that leverage the power of kindness—which recent research has highlighted as a powerful path toward greater empathy and compassion for others, along with greater well-being for the individual practicing kindness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="30b4836a-cf87-4606-903f-da3b2b542c4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="30b4836a-cf87-4606-903f-da3b2b542c4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Julie M. Fratantoni et al., “Parenting with a kind mind: Exploring kindness as a potentiator for enhanced brain health,” <em>Frontiers in Psychology</em>, March 2022, Volume 13, Article 805748; Joseph Chancellor et al., “Everyday prosociality in the workplace: The reinforcing benefits of giving, getting, and glimpsing,” <em>Emotion</em>, June 2018, Volume 18, Issue 4.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="" "" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/addressing%20employee%20burnout%20are%20you%20solving%20the%20right%20problem/rethinking-employee-mental-health-1351974509-thumb-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Addressing employee burnout: Are you solving the right problem?</div></h3><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-7"><p><div>Employers have invested unprecedented resources in employee mental health and well-being. With burnout at all-time highs, leaders wonder if they can make a difference. Our research suggests they can.</div></p></div></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>We also recommend employers <a href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem">revisit the following questions</a>:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Do we treat employee mental health and well-being as a strategic priority?</li>
    <li>Do we effectively address toxic behaviors?</li>
    <li>Do we create inclusive work environments?</li>
    <li>Do we promote sustainable work?</li>
    <li>Are we holding leaders accountable?</li>
    <li>Are we effectively tackling stigma?</li>
    <li>Do our resources meet employee needs?</li>
</ul>
<p>A long-term comprehensive approach is likely correlated to organizations gaining the full potential benefits from improved employee health. If individuals, businesses, and countries widen their understanding of health, they may be able reap the benefits of gains in life expectancy and quality of life.</p>
<p><em>If you’re experiencing a mental-health crisis, please contact a <a href="https://www.befrienders.org/need-to-talk">crisis help line</a> in your country (<a href="https://988lifeline.org/current-events/the-lifeline-and-988/">988</a> in the United States). For more information about World Mental Health Day, please refer to these resources from the <a href="https://www.who.int/campaigns/world-mental-health-day">World Health Organization</a>. If you are a leader who is concerned about mental-health challenges in your organization, please refer to these resources from the <a href="https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/mental-health-at-work">World Health Organization</a>. There are many actions that employers can take, including examples from: MindForward Alliance, One Mind at Work, Mental Health America, and Shatterproof.</em></p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/jacqueline-brassey">Jacqueline Brassey</a>, <a href="/our-people/erica-coe">Erica Coe</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/our-people/barbara-jeffery">Barbara Jeffery</a></strong> are co-leaders with the McKinsey Health Institute, where <strong>Renata Giarola, Brad Herbig,</strong> and <strong>Roxy Merkand</strong> are consultants.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Michaella Baker, Yueyang Chen, Nandita Daga, Martin Dewhurst, Kana Enomoto, Daisy Follett, Karen Henrie, David Mendelsohn, Hannah Mirman, Isidora Mitic, Andrea Pardo, and Curtis Stecyk for their contributions to this article.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Elizabeth Newman, an executive editor in the Chicago office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">Explore a career with us</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-center___ar3mu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/careers/search-jobs" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo mark World Mental Health Day 2022,\u003c/strong\u003e the World Health Organization has urged making \u0026ldquo;mental health and well-being for all a global priority.\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 1]] With the growing \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/unlocking-whole-person-care-through-behavioral-health\"\u003edisease burden related to brain-health conditions\u003c/a\u003e, moving this aspiration into reality requires bold action and deep commitment from a broad range of stakeholders\u0026mdash;with employers playing a critical role.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn our McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) publication, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem\"\u003eAddressing employee burnout: Are you solving the right problem?\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; we highlighted what affects employee mental health and \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/well-being-in-the-workplace\"\u003ewell-being\u003c/a\u003e. Now we examine who is most affected\u0026mdash;and how leaders are in a position to improve employee mental health and well-being at scale by rethinking the workplace via a lens of a \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years\"\u003emodern understanding of health\u003c/a\u003e. Research indicates that positive outcomes\u0026mdash;such as job satisfaction and work engagement\u0026mdash;are correlated with feeling included and supported, and with freedom from stigma or overwhelming \u003ca href=\"https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240057944\"\u003eworkloads\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe insights discussed below are based on a global survey MHI conducted across 15 countries and nearly 15,000 employees. To learn more, see the sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Survey scope and methodology.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 1]]\n[[story 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMoving to better mental health and well-being for employees everywhere\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs we have discussed in previous articles, employers have the opportunity to move \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/moving-the-needle-on-burnout\"\u003ethe needle on burnout\u003c/a\u003e, to explore ways to help \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/heat-waves-the-war-in-ukraine-and-stigma-gen-zs-perspectives-on-mental-health\"\u003eworkers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;struggling with mental-health and well-being challenges, and to explore ways to \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem\"\u003ecreate the healthiest environments for employees\u003c/a\u003e. As employers open the aperture to look beyond the reactive management of poor mental health to the proactive mitigation of its drivers, they can reinforce what is\u0026mdash;and is not\u0026mdash;acceptable. For example, companies may benefit from reinforcing behaviors that leverage the power of kindness\u0026mdash;which recent research has highlighted as a powerful path toward greater empathy and compassion for others, along with greater well-being for the individual practicing kindness.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe also recommend employers \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem\"\u003erevisit the following questions\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDo we treat employee mental health and well-being as a strategic priority?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDo we effectively address toxic behaviors?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDo we create inclusive work environments?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDo we promote sustainable work?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAre we holding leaders accountable?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAre we effectively tackling stigma?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDo our resources meet employee needs?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA long-term comprehensive approach is likely correlated to organizations gaining the full potential benefits from improved employee health. If individuals, businesses, and countries widen their understanding of health, they may be able reap the benefits of gains in life expectancy and quality of life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you\u0026rsquo;re experiencing a mental-health crisis, please contact a \u003ca href=\"https://www.befrienders.org/need-to-talk\"\u003ecrisis help line\u003c/a\u003e in your country (\u003ca href=\"https://988lifeline.org/current-events/the-lifeline-and-988/\"\u003e988\u003c/a\u003e in the United States). For more information about World Mental Health Day, please refer to these resources from the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.who.int/campaigns/world-mental-health-day\"\u003eWorld Health Organization\u003c/a\u003e. If you are a leader who is concerned about mental-health challenges in your organization, please refer to these resources from the \u003ca href=\"https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/mental-health-at-work\"\u003eWorld Health Organization\u003c/a\u003e. This survey involved nearly 15,000 employees in 15 countries: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, China, Egypt, France, Germany, India, Japan, Mexico, South Africa, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWorkplace factors assessed in our survey included:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eToxic workplace behavior\u003c/em\u003e: employees experience interpersonal behavior that leads them to feel unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInclusivity and belonging\u003c/em\u003e: organization systems, leaders, and peers foster a welcoming and fair environment for all employees to be themselves, find connection, and meaningfully contribute.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSustainable work\u003c/em\u003e: organizations and leaders promote work that enables a healthy balance between work and personal life, including a manageable workload and work schedule.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSupportive growth environment\u003c/em\u003e: managers care about employee opinions, well-being, and satisfaction and provide support and enable opportunities for growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFreedom from stigma and discrimination\u003c/em\u003e: there is freedom from the level of shame, prejudice, or discrimination employees perceive toward people with mental-health or substance-use conditions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOrganizational accountability\u003c/em\u003e: organizations gather feedback, track KPIs, align incentives, and measure progress against employee health goals.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLeadership commitment\u003c/em\u003e: leaders consider employee mental health a top priority, publicly committing to a clear strategy to improve employee mental health.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAccess to resources\u003c/em\u003e: organizations offer easy-to-use and accessible resources that fit individual employee needs related to mental health.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealth outcomes assessed in our survey included:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBurnout symptoms\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s experience of extreme tiredness, reduced ability to regulate cognitive and emotional processes, and mental distancing (Burnout Assessment Tool).[[footnote 2]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDistress\u003c/em\u003e: an employee experiencing a negative stress response, often involving negative affect and physiological reactivity (4DSQ Distress Screener).[[footnote 3]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDepression symptoms\u003c/em\u003e: an employee having little interest or pleasure in doing things, and feeling down, depressed, or hopeless (PHQ-2 Screener).[[footnote 4]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnxiety symptoms\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s feelings of nervousness, anxiousness, or being on edge, and not being able to stop or control worrying (GAD-2 Screener).[[footnote 5]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBusiness outcomes assessed in our survey included:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntent to leave\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s desire to leave the organization in which they are currently employed in the next three to six months.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWork engagement\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s positive motivational state of high energy combined with high levels of dedication and a strong focus on work.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOrganizational advocacy\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s willingness to recommend or endorse their organization as a place to work to friends and relatives.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWork satisfaction\u003c/em\u003e: an employee\u0026rsquo;s level of contentment or Our global survey finds that employees experiencing at least one mental-health and well-being challenge (nearly three in five)[[Footnote 2]] report worse employee experience metrics. They are three times more likely to experience toxic behaviors and four times more likely to want to leave their organization. They are also more likely to report low job satisfaction, engagement, or other signifiers of positive workplaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYet employees may be reluctant to mention mental-health or well-being challenges, as those facing mental-health challenges may grapple with stigma. As observed in a \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace\"\u003eprevious McKinsey survey\u003c/a\u003e, a substantial share of employees experiencing mental-health-related challenges indicated they would avoid treatment because they didn\u0026rsquo;t want anyone finding out.
